canonical_explanation.text: Our body has a skeleton made up of bones that gives shape, provides support, and protects internal organs. The skull protects the brain. The rib cage protects the heart and lungs. The backbone (spine) is made up of small bones called vertebrae and supports the body. Limb bones include the humerus (upper arm), femur (thigh bone, the longest bone). Joints are places where two or more bones meet. Hinge joints (knee, elbow) allow movement in one direction like a door. Ball-and-socket joints (shoulder, hip) allow movement in all directions. Pivot joints (neck) allow rotation. Fixed joints in the skull do not allow movement. Muscles are attached to bones and help us move. They work in pairs: when one muscle contracts (shortens), the other relaxes (lengthens). This is how we bend and straighten our arms and legs. Children have two sets of teeth: 20 milk teeth that fall out and are replaced by 32 permanent teeth. The four types are incisors (cutting), canines (tearing), premolars and molars (grinding). Good posture means sitting and standing straight. Carrying heavy school bags on both shoulders, exercising regularly, and eating calcium-rich foods like milk keep our bones and muscles healthy.
rules: Skeleton gives shape, support, and protects internal organs
Skull protects brain, rib cage protects heart and lungs
Backbone (spine) made of vertebrae, supports the body
Humerus (upper arm bone), femur (thigh bone, longest bone)
Hinge joint: knee, elbow (one direction movement)
Muscles work in pairs: one contracts, the other relaxes
Children have 20 milk teeth, adults have 32 permanent teeth
Incisors cut, canines tear, premolars and molars grind
Good posture: sit straight, carry bag properly
Calcium-rich food and exercise keep bones and muscles healthy

questions.question_text: What are the three main functions of the skeleton?

options.text: Giving shape, providing support, and protecting organs
Digesting food, pumping blood, and breathing

questions.explanation_correct: The skeleton has three main functions: it gives shape to our body, provides support so we can stand and sit, and protects important internal organs like the brain, heart, and lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Running, eating, sleeping are activities, not skeleton functions. Digesting and pumping blood are done by other organs. The skeleton specifically gives shape, provides support, and protects internal organs.

questions.question_text: Which bones protect the brain?
questions.explanation_correct: The skull is a hard, bony case that surrounds and protects the brain. It is made up of several bones joined together. The skull acts like a helmet for our brain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The rib cage protects the heart and lungs. The backbone supports the body. Leg bones help us walk and stand. It is the skull that forms a protective case around the brain.

questions.question_text: The rib cage protects which organs?
questions.explanation_correct: The rib cage is made up of 12 pairs of curved bones that form a cage around the heart and lungs. This protects these vital organs from injury.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is protected by the skull, not the rib cage. The rib cage specifically forms a protective enclosure around the heart and lungs in our chest area.

questions.question_text: The backbone is made up of small bones called:
questions.explanation_correct: The backbone (spine) is made up of small bones called vertebrae. There are 33 vertebrae stacked on top of each other. The spaces between them allow us to bend and twist our back.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ribs are the curved bones in the chest. Joints are where bones meet. Muscles help in movement. The small bones that make up the backbone are called vertebrae.

questions.question_text: Which is the longest bone in the human body?
questions.explanation_correct: The femur, or thigh bone, is the longest and strongest bone in the human body. It runs from the hip to the knee and supports the weight of our body when we stand, walk, or run.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The humerus is the upper arm bone, ribs are curved chest bones, and the backbone is made of many small vertebrae. The femur (thigh bone) is the longest single bone in the body.

questions.question_text: True or False: Without a skeleton, our body would be like a shapeless bag.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The skeleton gives our body its shape and structure. Without bones, we would not be able to stand, sit, or move. Our body would collapse like a bag with no framework.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Bones provide the rigid framework that gives our body its shape. Without the skeleton, we could not maintain our body shape or move.

questions.question_text: Ravi fell while playing cricket and hurt his head, but his brain was not injured. Which bone protected his brain?
questions.explanation_correct: Ravi's brain was protected by the skull. The skull is a hard, strong bone that covers the brain like a helmet, protecting it from injury when we fall or get hit on the head.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The backbone supports the body, the rib cage protects the chest organs, and the femur is the thigh bone. The skull is the bone that specifically protects the brain from injury.

questions.question_text: Why can we bend our backbone even though it is made of hard bones?

options.text: Because the backbone is actually soft
Because it is made of many small vertebrae with spaces between them
Because muscles make the backbone soft

questions.explanation_correct: The backbone can bend because it is made of many small bones (vertebrae) stacked together with flexible spaces (discs) between them. Each vertebra moves a little, and together they allow bending and twisting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The backbone is not soft, and individual bones cannot bend. The backbone is flexible because it is made of 33 small vertebrae with soft discs between them, allowing small movements at each joint.

questions.question_text: The upper arm bone is called the ________ and the thigh bone is called the ________.
questions.explanation_correct: The humerus is the bone in the upper arm (between shoulder and elbow), and the femur is the thigh bone (between hip and knee). The femur is the longest bone in the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The humerus is in the upper arm, not the thigh. The femur is in the thigh, not the arm. Vertebrae are in the backbone and ribs are in the chest. The correct answer is Humerus (arm) and Femur (thigh).

questions.question_text: A joint is a place where:
questions.explanation_correct: A joint is the place where two or more bones meet. Joints allow our body to move. Without joints, our body would be stiff and we could not bend, turn, or move.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscles help in movement, blood flows in blood vessels, and nerves carry messages. A joint specifically is the place where two or more bones meet and allow movement.

questions.question_text: The knee and elbow are examples of which type of joint?
questions.explanation_correct: The knee and elbow are hinge joints. They allow movement in only one direction, just like the hinge of a door allows it to open and close in one direction only.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ball-and-socket joints (shoulder, hip) allow movement in all directions. Pivot joints (neck) allow rotation. Fixed joints (skull) allow no movement. The knee and elbow are hinge joints that move in one direction.

questions.question_text: The shoulder joint allows movement in all directions. What type of joint is it?
questions.explanation_correct: The shoulder is a ball-and-socket joint. The round end of one bone (ball) fits into the cup-shaped hollow (socket) of another bone. This allows movement in all directions - up, down, front, back, and in circles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hinge joints only allow movement in one direction. Fixed joints don't move. Pivot joints allow rotation. The shoulder is a ball-and-socket joint that allows the widest range of movement.

questions.question_text: Which joint allows you to turn your head from side to side?
questions.explanation_correct: The pivot joint in the neck allows you to turn your head from side to side and tilt it. In a pivot joint, one bone rotates around another, like a key turning in a lock.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hinge joints bend in one direction, ball-and-socket joints move in all directions, and fixed joints don't move. The pivot joint in the neck specifically allows the rotating movement when you turn your head.

questions.question_text: The bones of the skull are joined by:
questions.explanation_correct: The bones of the skull are joined by fixed joints that do not allow any movement. This is important because the skull needs to be firm and rigid to protect the brain effectively.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The skull bones are connected by fixed joints, not movable ones. If the skull bones could move, they would not protect the brain properly. Fixed joints keep the skull bones locked in place.

questions.question_text: When you kick a football, which joint in your leg bends?
questions.explanation_correct: When you kick a football, your knee joint bends. The knee is a hinge joint that allows your lower leg to swing forward and kick the ball. It bends in one direction, just like a door hinge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The shoulder is in the arm, the neck is for head movement, and skull joints are fixed. When kicking a football, the knee joint (a hinge joint) in the leg bends to make the kicking motion.

questions.question_text: A bowler in cricket rotates his arm in a full circle. Which joint allows this movement?
questions.explanation_correct: A bowler rotates his arm in a full circle using the shoulder joint, which is a ball-and-socket joint. This joint allows movement in all directions, including the circular motion needed for bowling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hinge joints (knee, elbow) only move in one direction and cannot rotate in a circle. The pivot joint allows head rotation. Only the ball-and-socket joint at the shoulder allows the full circular arm movement.

questions.question_text:
Match the joint with its location:
1. Hinge joint - (a) Neck
2. Ball-and-socket joint - (b) Skull
3. Pivot joint - (c) Knee
4. Fixed joint - (d) Shoulder

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Hinge joint is at the knee (1-c), ball-and-socket joint at the shoulder (2-d), pivot joint at the neck (3-a), and fixed joint in the skull (4-b).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Knee = hinge (like a door), Shoulder = ball-and-socket (moves in all directions), Neck = pivot (turns/rotates), Skull = fixed (no movement). The correct matching is 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b.

questions.question_text: True or False: A hinge joint allows movement in all directions.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. A hinge joint allows movement in only ONE direction, like a door opening and closing. The joint that allows movement in all directions is the ball-and-socket joint.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Hinge joints (knee, elbow) move in only one direction. Ball-and-socket joints (shoulder, hip) are the ones that allow movement in all directions.

questions.question_text: What are muscles attached to?
questions.explanation_correct: Muscles are attached to bones by tough cord-like structures called tendons. When muscles pull on bones, our body parts move. This is how we walk, run, write, and do all our activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While muscles are under the skin, they are specifically attached to bones through tendons. When muscles contract (shorten), they pull on the bones to make them move.

questions.question_text: How do muscles work to move our body?

options.text: Only one muscle pushes the bone
Muscles work in pairs: one contracts while the other relaxes
All muscles contract at the same time

questions.explanation_correct: Muscles work in pairs. When you bend your arm, one muscle (bicep) contracts (shortens) while the opposite muscle (tricep) relaxes (lengthens). When you straighten your arm, the opposite happens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscles cannot push, they can only pull. They must work in pairs because a muscle can contract (pull) but cannot push a bone back. The partner muscle pulls it back the other way.

questions.question_text: When you bend your arm to lift a dumbbell, what happens to the muscles?

options.text: The muscle in front of the arm (bicep) contracts and the one behind (tricep) relaxes

questions.explanation_correct: When you bend your arm, the bicep (front muscle) contracts and gets shorter and thicker, pulling the lower arm up. At the same time, the tricep (back muscle) relaxes and stretches to allow the movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscles work in pairs. When bending the arm, the bicep in front contracts (pulls) while the tricep behind relaxes. If both contracted or both relaxed, the arm could not move properly.

questions.question_text: True or False: Muscles can only pull, they cannot push.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Muscles can only contract (shorten) which means they can only pull. They cannot push bones. This is why muscles work in pairs - one pulls one way and the partner pulls the other way.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Muscles can only pull by contracting. Since they cannot push, they must work in pairs to move bones in both directions.

questions.question_text: Why do muscles need to work in pairs?

options.text: Because muscles can only pull, so one pulls the bone one way and the other pulls it back
Because one muscle is stronger than the other

questions.explanation_correct: Muscles work in pairs because a muscle can only contract (pull) and cannot push. So one muscle pulls a bone in one direction, and its partner muscle pulls the bone back in the other direction. This allows two-way movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is not about tiredness, appearance, or strength. Since muscles can ONLY pull (by contracting), they need a partner to pull in the opposite direction. This pair system allows our bones to move both ways.

questions.question_text: What happens to muscles when we exercise regularly?
questions.explanation_correct: Regular exercise makes muscles stronger and healthier. When we exercise, our muscles work harder and grow stronger over time. This helps us do physical activities better and keeps our body fit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Exercise does not weaken or make muscles disappear. Regular exercise builds stronger, healthier muscles. This is why playing sports, running, and doing physical activities are important for children.

questions.question_text: Muscles are connected to bones by:
questions.explanation_correct: Tendons are tough, cord-like structures that connect muscles to bones. When a muscle contracts, it pulls on the tendon, which in turn pulls on the bone, causing movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nerves carry messages, blood vessels carry blood, and skin covers the body. Tendons are the specific structures that attach muscles to bones and transmit the pulling force.

questions.question_text: How many milk teeth does a child have?
questions.explanation_correct: A child has 20 milk teeth (also called baby teeth or deciduous teeth). These start appearing at about 6 months of age and are complete by about 2-3 years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Children have 20 milk teeth, not 12, 28, or 32. Adults eventually have 32 permanent teeth, but children start with 20 milk teeth that fall out as they grow.

questions.question_text: Which type of tooth is flat and sharp, used for cutting food?
questions.explanation_correct: Incisors are the flat, sharp front teeth that we use to cut and bite food. We have four incisors on top and four on the bottom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Canines are pointed for tearing. Molars and premolars are broad for grinding. Incisors are the flat, sharp front teeth designed for cutting and biting food.

questions.question_text: What is the best way to take care of your teeth?

options.text: Brush twice a day and eat less sugary food

questions.explanation_correct: The best way to care for teeth is to brush twice a day (morning and night), eat fewer sugary foods, eat calcium-rich foods like milk and cheese, and visit the dentist regularly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eating chocolates causes cavities. Brushing once a week is not enough. Never visiting the dentist means problems go undetected. Brushing twice daily and reducing sugar is the best dental care.

questions.question_text: What is good posture?
questions.explanation_correct: Good posture means sitting and standing straight with the backbone properly aligned. This prevents back pain, keeps the spine healthy, and allows the body to function properly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Slouching, bending forward, and lying while studying are all examples of bad posture that can hurt the backbone. Good posture means keeping the back straight when sitting and standing.

questions.question_text: Why should students carry their school bag on both shoulders?

options.text: Because it distributes weight evenly and protects the backbone

questions.explanation_correct: Carrying a bag on both shoulders distributes the weight evenly on the body. Carrying it on one shoulder puts all the weight on one side, which can cause back pain and may bend the spine over time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is about health, not appearance or rules. Carrying a heavy bag on one shoulder puts uneven pressure on the backbone and can cause posture problems. Both shoulders share the weight evenly.

questions.question_text: Which of these statements about the skeleton is INCORRECT?

options.text: The rib cage protects the heart and lungs
The backbone is made of one single bone
Bones give shape to our body

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that the backbone is one single bone is INCORRECT. The backbone is made of 33 small bones called vertebrae, not one single bone. This allows it to bend and twist.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The skull does protect the brain, the rib cage does protect the heart and lungs, and bones do give shape. The incorrect statement is about the backbone being one bone - it is actually made of 33 vertebrae.

questions.question_text: A joint that allows movement in only one direction, like a door hinge, is called a ________ joint.
questions.explanation_correct: A hinge joint allows movement in only one direction, just like the hinge on a door that allows it to open and close but not twist. The knee and elbow are examples of hinge joints.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ball-and-socket joints move in all directions. Pivot joints allow rotation. Fixed joints don't move at all. A joint that moves in only one direction, like a door, is called a hinge joint.

questions.question_text: Which food helps make bones strong?
questions.explanation_correct: Milk, cheese, and curd are rich in calcium, which is essential for strong bones and teeth. Children especially need calcium-rich foods for proper bone growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chips, cold drinks, chocolates, and sweets do not help build strong bones. Only calcium-rich foods like milk, cheese, curd, and green vegetables help make bones strong and healthy.

questions.question_text: The hip joint is a ball-and-socket joint. What movement does it allow?
questions.explanation_correct: The hip is a ball-and-socket joint that allows movement in all directions - forward, backward, sideways, and in circles. This is why you can swing your legs in many different ways.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ball-and-socket joints like the hip allow the widest range of movement - in all directions. One-direction movement is for hinge joints, no movement for fixed joints, and only rotation for pivot joints.

questions.question_text: If muscles did not work in pairs, what would happen?

options.text: We could bend a joint but not straighten it back

questions.explanation_correct: If muscles did not work in pairs, we could bend a joint (one muscle pulls) but could not straighten it back (no partner muscle to pull it back). We need the pair to move bones in both directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Without muscle pairs, movement would be incomplete. Since muscles can only pull (not push), a single muscle could only move a bone one way. The partner muscle is needed to pull it back.

questions.question_text: An adult has how many permanent teeth?
questions.explanation_correct: An adult has 32 permanent teeth. These include 8 incisors, 4 canines, 8 premolars, and 12 molars (including 4 wisdom teeth). Children have 20 milk teeth that are replaced by 32 permanent teeth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Children have 20 milk teeth, but adults have 32 permanent teeth. This includes incisors, canines, premolars, and molars including wisdom teeth.

questions.question_text: True or False: Eating too many sweets can cause tooth decay (cavities).
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Sugary foods like sweets, chocolates, and cold drinks feed the germs (bacteria) on our teeth. These germs produce acid that destroys the tooth enamel, causing holes called cavities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Sugar feeds bacteria on teeth, which produce acids that create cavities (holes in teeth). That is why limiting sugary foods and brushing regularly is important.

questions.question_text:
Match the bone with the organ it protects:
1. Skull - (a) Heart and lungs
2. Rib cage - (b) Spinal cord
3. Backbone - (c) Brain

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Skull protects the brain (1-c), Rib cage protects the heart and lungs (2-a), and Backbone protects the spinal cord (3-b).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember: Skull = brain, Rib cage = heart and lungs, Backbone = spinal cord. The correct matching is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b.

questions.question_text: After running a race, Anya's legs feel tired. Why?

options.text: Because her muscles have been working hard and need rest
Because her joints have stopped working
Because she did not eat enough salt

questions.explanation_correct: When we run, the leg muscles contract and relax repeatedly. After a lot of exercise, the muscles get tired because they have used up energy. Resting allows the muscles to recover.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bones do not get tired, joints do not stop working, and salt is not the issue. When we exercise hard, our muscles use up energy and become tired. They need rest to recover.

questions.question_text: Why is it important to sit straight while studying at a desk?

options.text: It keeps your backbone healthy and prevents back pain

questions.explanation_correct: Sitting straight (good posture) keeps the backbone properly aligned and prevents back pain. Slouching or bending for long periods puts stress on the spine and muscles, which can cause pain and problems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Good posture is about health, not appearance or speed. Sitting straight keeps the backbone in its natural curve, preventing strain on the spine and back muscles. Poor posture can lead to long-term back problems.

questions.question_text: An X-ray shows that a person has broken the humerus. Where is the injury?
questions.explanation_correct: The humerus is the bone in the upper arm (between the shoulder and elbow). If the humerus is broken, the injury is in the upper arm. The thigh bone is called the femur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The humerus is located in the upper arm, not in the thigh (that is the femur), chest (ribs), or head (skull). A broken humerus means the person has injured their upper arm.

questions.question_text: When one muscle in a pair ________ (shortens), the other muscle ________ (lengthens).
questions.explanation_correct: When one muscle contracts (shortens and pulls), the other muscle in the pair relaxes (lengthens). This alternating pattern of contraction and relaxation is how muscles produce movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscles contract (shorten) to pull and relax (lengthen) to allow the other muscle to pull. They do not push. The correct pair of actions is: one contracts while the other relaxes.

questions.question_text: Why do fixed joints in the skull not allow movement?

options.text: Because skull bones are very small
Because the brain needs firm, steady protection
Because there are no muscles on the skull
Because the skull is made of soft bone

questions.explanation_correct: The skull bones are joined by fixed joints because the brain needs firm, steady protection. If the skull bones could move, the brain would be at risk of damage from even small bumps or movements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is protection. The brain is a very delicate and important organ that needs a rigid, non-moving protective covering. Fixed joints keep the skull bones locked tightly to provide maximum protection.

questions.question_text: Which of these activities helps keep BOTH bones and muscles healthy?

options.text: Playing outdoor games and drinking milk

questions.explanation_correct: Playing outdoor games exercises the muscles and makes them strong. Drinking milk provides calcium for strong bones. Together, physical activity and good nutrition keep both bones and muscles healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Watching TV and sleeping do not exercise muscles. Eating only sweets does not provide calcium for bones. Playing outdoor games and drinking milk together benefit both muscles (through exercise) and bones (through calcium).

questions.question_text: True or False: The femur (thigh bone) is the smallest bone in the body.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The femur (thigh bone) is the LONGEST and STRONGEST bone in the body, not the smallest. The smallest bone is the stapes, found in the ear.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. The femur is the longest and strongest bone in the body. It runs from the hip to the knee and supports the body's weight.

questions.question_text: When you nod your head up and down to say 'yes', which type of joint allows this?
questions.explanation_correct: The pivot joint in the neck allows the head to nod up and down (yes) and also to turn side to side (no). The pivot joint lets the skull rotate and tilt on top of the backbone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The movement of nodding your head is controlled by the pivot joint at the top of the neck. Hinge joints move in one plane, ball-and-socket joints are in shoulders/hips, and fixed joints do not move.

questions.question_text: When do milk teeth start to fall out?
questions.explanation_correct: Milk teeth usually start falling out around age 6-7 years. Permanent teeth push up from below and replace the milk teeth. This process continues until about age 12-13.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk teeth do not fall at age 1-2 (they are still growing then) or at 15-16 (they are already replaced by then). Milk teeth start falling out around age 6-7 and are replaced by permanent teeth.

questions.question_text: About how many bones are there in the adult human body?
questions.explanation_correct: An adult human body has about 206 bones. Babies are born with about 300 bones, but as they grow, some bones fuse together, reducing the number to about 206 in adults.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The adult human body does not have 50, 106, or 506 bones. It has approximately 206 bones, which form the complete skeleton that supports and protects the body.

questions.question_text: Which of these is TRUE about muscles and bones?

options.text: Bones move on their own without muscles
Muscles are attached to bones and pull them to cause movement
Muscles push bones to make them move

questions.explanation_correct: Muscles are attached to bones by tendons and PULL on the bones to make them move. Bones cannot move on their own. The pulling action of muscles on bones is what allows all our body movements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bones cannot move without muscles. Muscles PULL (not push) on bones. Bones are harder than muscles. The true statement is that muscles attach to bones and pull them to cause movement.

questions.question_text: Sita's mother says she should drink milk every day and play outside. How does this help her body?

options.text: Milk makes her smart and playing makes her tired
Milk provides calcium for strong bones and playing exercises her muscles
Milk quenches thirst and playing passes time

questions.explanation_correct: Milk is rich in calcium and proteins, which make bones and teeth strong. Playing outdoor games exercises muscles, making them stronger. Together, they keep both the skeletal and muscular systems healthy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Milk does more than quench thirst - it provides calcium for bones. Playing does more than pass time - it strengthens muscles. Together, milk and exercise keep the bones and muscles healthy and strong.
